events.name: Battle of Megiddo
events.story: Around 1457 BCE, Pharaoh Thutmose III led Egyptian forces to victory over a coalition of Canaanite kings near Megiddo. This is considered the first recorded battle in human history, documented in detailed inscriptions on temple walls.
events.hint-1: This was the first recorded battle in human history.
events.hint-2: It involved Pharaoh Thutmose III and a coalition of Canaanite kings.
events.hint-3: It took place in a location whose name later inspired 'Armageddon'.

events.name: Construction of the Great Pyramids of Giza
events.story: Around 2600 BCE, the Egyptians began constructing the Great Pyramids at Giza during the Fourth Dynasty. Built as tombs for the pharaohs Khufu, Khafre, and Menkaure, these monumental structures became enduring symbols of ancient engineering and power.
events.hint-1: These structures were built as tombs for pharaohs.
events.hint-2: They are one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
events.hint-3: You can still see them near modern-day Cairo.

events.name: Code of Hammurabi Inscribed
events.story: Around 1750 BCE, King Hammurabi of Babylon established one of the earliest known sets of written laws. Inscribed on a basalt stele, the Code of Hammurabi outlined legal standards, punishments, and social order in Mesopotamian society.
events.hint-1: This artifact contains one of the earliest written legal codes.
events.hint-2: It was created by a Babylonian king.
events.hint-3: Its motto could be summarized as 'an eye for an eye'.

events.name: The Trojan War
events.story: According to ancient Greek legend, the Trojan War took place around 1200 BCE when Greek forces besieged the city of Troy after Paris of Troy abducted Helen of Sparta. The epic tales of this war were immortalized in Homer's Iliad and Odyssey.
events.hint-1: This legendary conflict inspired Homer's Iliad.
events.hint-2: It was sparked by the abduction of Helen.
events.hint-3: A famous 'wooden horse' played a key role in its end.

events.name: Establishment of the Roman Republic
events.story: In 509 BCE, the Roman people overthrew their last king, Lucius Tarquinius Superbus, ending the Roman monarchy. In its place, they established the Roman Republic — a new system of government led by elected consuls and a senate. This marked the beginning of Rome’s transformation into a dominant power in the ancient world.
events.hint-1: This event ended Rome’s period of kings.
events.hint-2: It introduced a system led by consuls and a senate.
events.hint-3: It laid the foundation for what would become the Roman Empire.

events.name: Construction of the Parthenon
events.story: Between 447 and 432 BCE, the ancient Athenians built the Parthenon atop the Acropolis under the leadership of Pericles. Dedicated to the goddess Athena, the temple symbolized the height of Classical Greek architecture and Athenian power.
events.hint-1: A temple dedicated to the goddess Athena.
events.hint-2: It stands atop a famous hill overlooking Athens.
events.hint-3: Its architecture defines the Classical Greek style.

events.name: Battle of Issus
events.story: In 333 BCE, Alexander the Great faced the Persian king Darius III near the town of Issus in southern Anatolia. Despite being outnumbered, Alexander’s tactical brilliance led to a decisive victory, forcing Darius to flee and marking a major turning point in the conquest of the Persian Empire.
events.hint-1: This battle forced the Persian king Darius III to flee.
events.hint-2: It occurred in southern Anatolia near the Mediterranean coast.
events.hint-3: It was one of Alexander the Great’s most decisive early victories.

events.name: Founding of the Qin Dynasty and the Terracotta Army
events.story: In 221 BCE, Qin Shi Huang unified the warring states and declared himself the First Emperor of China, founding the Qin Dynasty. Near his mausoleum, thousands of clay soldiers—today called the Terracotta Army—were buried to protect him in the afterlife.
events.hint-1: This dynasty unified China for the first time.
events.hint-2: Its emperor began building the Great Wall.
events.hint-3: Thousands of clay soldiers guard his tomb.

events.name: Julius Caesar Crosses the Rubicon
events.story: In 49 BCE, Julius Caesar crossed the Rubicon River with his army, defying the Roman Senate and igniting a civil war. The act became symbolic of making an irreversible decision.
events.hint-1: This act started a Roman civil war.
events.hint-2: It is associated with the phrase 'the die is cast'.
events.hint-3: It involved crossing a small river in northern Italy.

events.name: Assassination of Julius Caesar
events.story: In 44 BCE, Julius Caesar was assassinated by Roman senators led by Brutus and Cassius. The attack took place during a Senate meeting, drastically altering the future of the Roman Republic.
events.hint-1: It happened on the Ides of March.
events.hint-2: The victim was stabbed by political rivals.
events.hint-3: This event paved the way for the Roman Empire.

events.name: Birth of Jesus of Nazareth
events.story: Around 4 BCE, Jesus of Nazareth was born in Bethlehem during the reign of Herod the Great. His life and teachings later became the foundation of Christianity.
events.hint-1: This birth is celebrated on December 25 by many.
events.hint-2: It took place in a town south of Jerusalem.
events.hint-3: It is central to the Christian faith.

events.name: Eruption of Mount Vesuvius and Destruction of Pompeii
events.story: In 79 CE, Mount Vesuvius erupted catastrophically, burying the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum under ash and pumice. The disaster preserved the towns remarkably well, providing an unparalleled view of Roman daily life.
events.hint-1: A volcanic eruption froze an entire city in time.
events.hint-2: The volcano is located near the Bay of Naples.
events.hint-3: Ash and pumice buried the inhabitants and buildings.

events.name: Construction of the Colosseum
events.story: Completed in 80 CE under Emperor Titus, the Colosseum became Rome’s greatest amphitheater. It hosted gladiatorial games, public spectacles, and massive crowds, symbolizing the engineering might of the Roman Empire.
events.hint-1: This structure hosted gladiator fights.
events.hint-2: It is one of the most famous landmarks in Rome.
events.hint-3: It could hold tens of thousands of spectators.

events.name: Unification of Japan under Tokugawa Ieyasu
events.story: Following decades of internal warfare, Tokugawa Ieyasu defeated rival clans, establishing the Tokugawa Shogunate and ushering in over 250 years of stability in Japan.
events.hint-1: The decisive battle was Sekigahara.
events.hint-2: This began a long era of isolation.
events.hint-3: The capital became Edo, now a major modern city.

events.name: Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand
events.story: On June 28, 1914, Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria and his wife Sophie were assassinated in Sarajevo by Gavrilo Princip, a member of the Black Hand movement. The incident directly triggered World War I.
events.hint-1: This assassination sparked World War I.
events.hint-2: It happened in Sarajevo.
events.hint-3: The target was heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne.

events.name: Hindenburg Disaster
events.story: On May 6, 1937, the German passenger airship LZ 129 Hindenburg caught fire and was destroyed while attempting to land in New Jersey. The iconic photograph of the airship engulfed in flames became one of the most famous images of the 20th century.
events.hint-1: It involved a German airship.
events.hint-2: The disaster occurred while docking.
events.hint-3: The photo shows a massive airship engulfed in flames.

events.name: Storming of the Winter Palace
events.story: In October 1917, Bolshevik forces stormed the Winter Palace in Petrograd, overthrowing the Provisional Government. Although many of the images were staged afterward, the event is widely documented and symbolized the rise of Soviet power.
events.hint-1: This event marked the rise of the Bolsheviks.
events.hint-2: It took place in Russia’s imperial capital.
events.hint-3: It is associated with the October Revolution.

events.name: Attack on Pearl Harbor
events.story: On December 7, 1941, the Imperial Japanese Navy launched a surprise attack on Pearl Harbor in Hawaii. Photographs of the burning battleships shocked the world and led to the United States entering World War II.
events.hint-1: This attack led the U.S. to enter World War II.
events.hint-2: Battleships were photographed burning.
events.hint-3: It occurred in Hawaii.

events.name: D-Day Landings
events.story: On June 6, 1944, Allied forces stormed the beaches of Normandy during World War II. Robert Capa’s photographs of soldiers landing under fire remain some of the most striking images of the war.
events.hint-1: This was the largest amphibious invasion in history.
events.hint-2: It occurred on the coast of Normandy.
events.hint-3: Famous photographs show soldiers struggling ashore.

events.name: Raising a Flag Over the Reichstag
events.story: On May 2, 1945, Soviet troops raised the flag of the USSR above the Reichstag in Berlin. The photograph became a symbol of the defeat of Nazi Germany and the Soviet victory in Europe.
events.hint-1: It symbolizes the fall of Nazi Germany.
events.hint-2: The Soviet flag is prominently featured.
events.hint-3: It happened in Berlin.

events.name: Partition of India
events.story: In 1947, British India was divided into two independent nations: India and Pakistan. Mass migration and communal violence followed, and iconic photographs show overcrowded trains carrying refugees.
events.hint-1: This event involved massive migration.
events.hint-2: It resulted in the creation of two nations.
events.hint-3: Famous photos show overcrowded trains.

events.name: Incheon Landing
events.story: On September 15, 1950, UN forces led by General Douglas MacArthur conducted a surprise amphibious landing at Incheon during the Korean War. The operation was photographed extensively and marked a major turning point.
events.hint-1: This landing reversed early war losses.
events.hint-2: It was led by General MacArthur.
events.hint-3: It occurred during the Korean War.

events.name: Cuban Missile Crisis U-2 Photographs
events.story: In October 1962, U-2 reconnaissance aircraft photographed Soviet missile installations in Cuba. These images triggered the Cuban Missile Crisis, bringing the world to the brink of nuclear war.
events.hint-1: Spy photos revealed missile sites.
events.hint-2: This triggered a major Cold War standoff.
events.hint-3: It involved the U.S., USSR, and Cuba.

events.name: The Napalm Girl
events.story: On June 8, 1972, a South Vietnamese plane mistakenly dropped napalm on Trang Bang. The photograph of a young girl, Phan Thi Kim Phuc, running in agony became one of the most unforgettable images of the Vietnam War.
events.hint-1: The photograph shows children running in terror.
events.hint-2: It is one of the most famous images of the Vietnam War.
events.hint-3: Napalm was accidentally dropped.

events.name: Tank Man
events.story: On June 5, 1989, during the Tiananmen Square protests, a lone man stood in front of a column of tanks, creating one of the most iconic images of peaceful resistance in history.
events.hint-1: This image shows a lone man blocking tanks.
events.hint-2: It took place in a large public square.
events.hint-3: It occurred during pro-democracy protests.

events.name: Fall of the Berlin Wall
events.story: In November 1989, East and West Berliners gathered to dismantle the Berlin Wall. Photographs show people climbing, hammering, and celebrating its collapse.
events.hint-1: This event reunited a divided city.
events.hint-2: People celebrated by breaking concrete.
events.hint-3: It marked the end of the Cold War era.

events.name: Rwandan Genocide
events.story: In 1994, mass violence erupted in Rwanda, resulting in the deaths of an estimated 800,000 Tutsi and moderate Hutu. Photographs documented refugees, roadblocks, and the humanitarian crisis.
events.hint-1: This tragedy unfolded in Central Africa.
events.hint-2: It involved mass ethnic violence.
events.hint-3: Photographs show refugee columns and devastation.

events.name: September 11 Attacks
events.story: On September 11, 2001, coordinated terrorist attacks struck the United States, including the World Trade Center. Photographs show the towers burning after the hijacked planes struck.
events.hint-1: The event involved hijacked airplanes.
events.hint-2: It struck two massive skyscrapers.
events.hint-3: It occurred in the United States’ largest city.

events.name: 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami
events.story: On December 26, 2004, a massive undersea megathrust earthquake triggered one of the deadliest tsunamis in history, devastating coastlines across Indonesia, Thailand, Sri Lanka, and India. Many photographs captured the waves hitting coastal cities.
events.hint-1: A massive earthquake triggered this disaster.
events.hint-2: Southeast Asia was heavily affected.
events.hint-3: It is one of the most photographed natural disasters in history.
